fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that f is monic. Let e\colon E\rightarrowtail A \times A be the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{1} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{2}. Then it follows that f\pi _{1}e = f\pi _{2}e. Since f is monic, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e. Then it follows that e factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket x = x'\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}.
Assume the converse. Suppose that fu = fv for some parallel pair of morphisms u,v\colon C\rightrightarrows A. Then it follows that (u,v) factors through e.
Thus, u = \pi _{1}(u,v) = \pi _{1}ew and v = \pi _{2}(u,v) = \pi _{2}ew. By assumption, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e so u = v.
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a monomorphism iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x,x'\colon A|f(x) = f(x') \vdash x = x' in its internal language.

Suppose that f is monic. Let e\colon E\rightarrowtail A \times A be the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{1} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{2}. Then it follows that f\pi _{1}e = f\pi _{2}e. Since f is monic, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e. Then it follows that e factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket x = x'\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}.
Assume the converse. Suppose that fu = fv for some parallel pair of morphisms u,v\colon C\rightrightarrows A. Then it follows that (u,v) factors through e.
Thus, u = \pi _{1}(u,v) = \pi _{1}ew and v = \pi _{2}(u,v) = \pi _{2}ew. By assumption, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e so u = v.
